function_info.name: DetermineFirstPeriodCanceledByFromDate
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [CrisNationalGridWest].[DetermineFirstPeriodCanceledByFromDate]
(
      @FromDate dbo.FromDate
)
RETURNS varchar(6)
AS
BEGIN
            --******************************************************************************************************
            --* Description:  calcualtes the top billing period that encapsulates the fromdate and then returns that period -1
            --*                           INDEPENDENT on the WDNumber. the period is defined by all the dates between 01 and 21 or 21 and 01 (dependant on the period) 
            --* Mohammed Belarrem
            --*   05/26/2010 MOH    created:    
            --*   06/02/2010 MOH    update:     National Grid has 0 WD numbers when they catch up with meter reads
            --*                                       this causes some of the todates to be outside the range of 01-20 or 21-40
            --*                                       instead they should be bound by the next 21 or 01     
            --*	  07/20/2010 MOH	update:		Based on Peter's suggestion to use 20 & 40 WorDays instead of 01 & 20		   
            --******************************************************************************************************

            declare @BillingPeriod dbo.BillingPeriod
			
			/* Iteration 1
            SELECT TOP 1 @BillingPeriod = dbo.CreatePreviousPeriod(BillingPeriod, 'M')
            SELECT TOP 1 @BillingPeriod = BillingPeriod
            FROM CrisNationalGridWest.CRISBillingPeriodByWD
            WHERE WDNumber IN ('01', '21') AND @FromDate < ToDate
            ORDER BY BillingPeriod asc
			*/
			
			/* Iteration 2
			SELECT TOP (1)  @BillingPeriod = BillingPeriod
			FROM CrisNationalGridWest.CRISBillingPeriodByWD
			WHERE (WDNumber IN ('01', '21')) AND (ToDate >= @FromDate ) AND (FromDate < @FromDate )
            
            return dbo.CreateNextPeriod(@BillingPeriod , 'M')  
			*/
			
			
			/* Iteration 3*/	            
  			SELECT TOP (1)  @BillingPeriod = BillingPeriod
			FROM CrisNationalGridWest.CRISBillingPeriodByWD
			WHERE (WDNumber IN ('20', '40')) AND (ToDate >= @FromDate ) AND (FromDate < @FromDate )
            
            return dbo.CreateNextPeriod(@BillingPeriod , 'M')  

      

END

function_info.name: DetermineFromDateFromBillingPeriodAndWDNumber
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [CrisNationalGridWest].[DetermineFromDateFromBillingPeriodAndWDNumber]
(
      @WDNumber varchar(2),
      @BillingPeriod varchar(6)
)
RETURNS varchar(8)
AS
BEGIN
            --******************************************************************************************************
            --* Description: Returns the fromDate from the meter reading schedule based on the billing period and the WDNumber 
            --*	
            --* 06/02/2010 PAH: Creation			 
            --* 06/02/2010 MOH: Update: Modified it to take into consideration the other WDNumber ( '21' if '01' etc)
            --* 09/10/2010 MOH: BUG FIX: the function was returning the ToDate Instead of the FromDate			 
            --******************************************************************************************************

            declare @FromDate varchar(8)
			DECLARE @TheOtherWDNumber VARCHAR(2)
			
			SET @TheOtherWDNumber = CASE WHEN (@WDNumber < '21') THEN CAST( CAST(@WDNumber AS int) + 20 AS VARCHAR(2))
										 WHEN (@WDNumber = '40') THEN '20'
										 ELSE CAST( CAST(@WDNumber AS int) % 20 AS VARCHAR(2))
									END

			SET @TheOtherWDNumber = RIGHT( '00' + @TheOtherWDNumber , 2)
			
			SELECT  @FromDate = FromDate
			FROM CrisNationalGridWest.CRISBillingPeriodByWD
			WHERE (BillingPeriod = @BillingPeriod) AND ( (WDNumber = @WDNumber) OR (WDNumber = @TheOtherWDNumber))      
			       
            return @FromDate   
      

END

function_info.name: DetermineNewCRISBillingPeriodRevisionAdjustment
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [CrisNationalGridWest].[DetermineNewCRISBillingPeriodRevisionAdjustment]
(
	  @SpecialLedgerNumber11 varchar(11),
      @InitialTodateBillingPeriod dbo.yyyymm,
      @CurrentBillingPeriod dbo.yyyymm
)
RETURNS varchar(6)
AS
BEGIN
            --******************************************************************************************************
            --* Description:  calculates the top billing period that encapsulates the todate INDEPENDENT on the WDNumber.
            --*                           the period is defined by all the dates between 01 and 21 or 21 and 01 (dependant on the period) 
            --*                           
            --* Mohammed Belarrem
            --*   05/26/2010 MOH    created:    
            --*   06/02/2010 MOH    update:     National Grid has 0 WD numbers when they catch up with meter reads
            --*                                       this causes some of the todates to be outside the range of 01-20 or 21-40
            --*                                       instead they should be bound by the next 21 or 01     
            --******************************************************************************************************

            declare @BillingPeriod dbo.BillingPeriod
            declare @GasToDateBillingPeriodRevision dbo.BillingPeriod
            declare @Rows int
            --
            if(@InitialTodateBillingPeriod > @CurrentBillingPeriod) set @InitialTodateBillingPeriod = @CurrentBillingPeriod
			SELECT 
					@GasToDateBillingPeriodRevision = CrisNationalGridWest.LastBillingPeriodAccountInSepecialLedger.FirstNewCRISBillingPeriodRevision
			FROM 
					CrisNationalGridWest.UploadAccountBillingDetail INNER JOIN
					CrisNationalGridWest.LastBillingPeriodAccountInSepecialLedger ON 
					CrisNationalGridWest.UploadAccountBillingDetail.SpecialLedgerAccountNUmber = CrisNationalGridWest.LastBillingPeriodAccountInSepecialLedger.SpecialLedgerNumber11
			WHERE 
					(CrisNationalGridWest.LastBillingPeriodAccountInSepecialLedger.SpecialLedgerNumber11 = @SpecialLedgerNumber11) AND 
					(CrisNationalGridWest.UploadAccountBillingDetail.SpecialLedgerAccountNUmber IS NOT NULL)
			set @Rows = @@ROWCOUNT
			if (@Rows = 0) return @InitialTodateBillingPeriod

            return case when @GasToDateBillingPeriodRevision >= @InitialTodateBillingPeriod  then @GasToDateBillingPeriodRevision else @InitialTodateBillingPeriod end  
      

END

CREATE  FUNCTION [CrisNationalGridWest].[DetermineNewCRISFirstPeriodCanceledAdjustment]
(
	  @SpecialLedgerNumber11 varchar(11),
      @InitialFirstPeriodCanceled dbo.yyyymm,
      @CurrentBillingPeriod dbo.yyyymm
)
RETURNS varchar(6)
AS
BEGIN
            --******************************************************************************************************
            --* Description:  calcualtes the top billing period that encapsulates the fromdate and then returns that period -1
            --*                           INDEPENDENT on the WDNumber. the period is defined by all the dates between 01 and 21 or 21 and 01 (dependant on the period) 
            --* Mohammed Belarrem
            --*   06/30/2010 PAH    created:    
            --******************************************************************************************************

            declare @BillingPeriod dbo.BillingPeriod
            declare @FirstNewCRISBillingPeriodRevision dbo.BillingPeriod
            
			SELECT 
					@FirstNewCRISBillingPeriodRevision = CrisNationalGridWest.LastBillingPeriodAccountInSepecialLedger.FirstNewCRISBillingPeriodRevision
			FROM 
					CrisNationalGridWest.UploadAccountBillingDetail INNER JOIN
					CrisNationalGridWest.LastBillingPeriodAccountInSepecialLedger ON 
					CrisNationalGridWest.UploadAccountBillingDetail.SpecialLedgerAccountNUmber = CrisNationalGridWest.LastBillingPeriodAccountInSepecialLedger.SpecialLedgerNumber11
			WHERE 
					(CrisNationalGridWest.LastBillingPeriodAccountInSepecialLedger.SpecialLedgerNumber11 = @SpecialLedgerNumber11) AND 
					(CrisNationalGridWest.UploadAccountBillingDetail.SpecialLedgerAccountNUmber IS NOT NULL)
			
			select @BillingPeriod =  case when @InitialFirstPeriodCanceled < @FirstNewCRISBillingPeriodRevision  then @FirstNewCRISBillingPeriodRevision else @InitialFirstPeriodCanceled end  	
			--
            return  case when @BillingPeriod >  @CurrentBillingPeriod  then @CurrentBillingPeriod else @BillingPeriod end  
      

END

function_info.name: DetermineThermFactorByAccountAndPeriods
function_info.definition:
-- User Defined Function

CREATE FUNCTION [CrisNationalGridWest].[DetermineThermFactorByAccountAndPeriods](@AccountNumber dbo.acctnum, @BillingPeriodRevision dbo.BillingPeriod, @FirstBillingPeriodCanceled BillingPeriod, @TransactionCode VARCHAR(2) )
RETURNS dbo.ThermsFactor as
begin

		--**********************************************************************************************************************************************
		--*
		--*	Description: returns the ThermsFactor associated with the specific account for the specific range of periods
		--*
		--* Created by Mohammed Belarrem
		--*
		--* LOG	11/08/2010 MOH	Create
		--*		11/08/2010 MOH	Update:	Added the TransactionCode to be more accurate
		--*		11/09/2010 MOH	Update:	Added a condition to enlarge the set in case there are no results
		--*		11/29/2010 MOH	Update:	Added the default value @ThermsFactor 1.0297 as fudge
		--**********************************************************************************************************************************************


		DECLARE @ThermsFactor dbo.ThermsFactor


		SELECT TOP 1   @ThermsFactor =  thermFactor
		FROM CrisNationalGridWest.UploadAccountBillingDetail
		WHERE AccountNumber = @AccountNumber  AND BillingPeriodRevision >= @BillingPeriodRevision AND FirstBillingPeriodCanceled <= @FirstBillingPeriodCanceled  AND TransactionCode = @TransactionCode 

		-- in case there is no result, try a larger set

		IF (@ThermsFactor IS NULL OR @ThermsFactor = 0)
		BEGIN
			SELECT TOP 1   @ThermsFactor =  thermFactor
			FROM CrisNationalGridWest.UploadAccountBillingDetail
			WHERE AccountNumber = @AccountNumber  AND BillingPeriodRevision >= @BillingPeriodRevision AND FirstBillingPeriodCanceled <= @FirstBillingPeriodCanceled

		END


		-- if that doenst work try to get the latest value
		IF (@ThermsFactor IS NULL OR @ThermsFactor = 0)
		BEGIN
			SELECT TOP 1   @ThermsFactor =  thermFactor
			FROM CrisNationalGridWest.UploadAccountBillingDetail
			WHERE AccountNumber = @AccountNumber 
			ORDER BY BillingPeriodRevision DESC 

		END

	-- and if that doenst work try to get the latest value
		IF (@ThermsFactor IS NULL OR @ThermsFactor = 0)
		BEGIN
			-- set a default value
			SET @ThermsFactor = 1.0297

		END

		RETURN ISNULL(@ThermsFactor, 1.0297)

end

function_info.name: DetermineToDateFromBillingPeriodAndWDNumber
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [CrisNationalGridWest].[DetermineToDateFromBillingPeriodAndWDNumber]
(
      @WDnumber varchar(2),
      @BillingPeriod varchar(6)
)
RETURNS varchar(8)
AS
BEGIN
            --******************************************************************************************************
            --* Description: Returns the ToDate from the meter reading schedule based on the billing period and the WDNumber 
            --*	
            --* 06/02/2010 PAH: Creation			 
            --* 06/02/2010 MOH: Update: Modified it to take into consideration the other WDNumber ( '21' if '01' etc)			 
            --******************************************************************************************************

            declare @ToDate varchar(8)
			DECLARE @TheOtherWDNumber VARCHAR(2)
			
			SET @TheOtherWDNumber = CASE WHEN (@WDNumber < '21') THEN CAST( CAST(@WDNumber AS int) + 20 AS VARCHAR(2))
										 WHEN (@WDNumber = '40') THEN '20'
										 ELSE CAST( CAST(@WDNumber AS int) % 20 AS VARCHAR(2))
									END

			SET @TheOtherWDNumber = RIGHT( '00' + @TheOtherWDNumber , 2)

            
			SELECT  @ToDate = ToDate
			FROM CrisNationalGridWest.CRISBillingPeriodByWD
			WHERE (BillingPeriod = @BillingPeriod) AND ( (WDNumber = @WDNumber) OR (WDNumber = @TheOtherWDNumber))      
			       
            return @ToDate   
      

END

-- =============================================

-- =============================================
CREATE FUNCTION [CrisNationalGridWest].[EccsCancelBumpAccountTenantNumber] (@AccountNumber varchar(12),@TransactionCode char(2) )
RETURNS    varchar(12)
BEGIN 
	DECLARE @ReversedAccountNumber varchar(12)
	declare @AccountNumberLength int
	declare @LastDigit int
	declare @SignValue int
	declare @overPunchValuePosition int
	Declare @overPunchColumnLength int
	declare @convertedField varchar(1000)
	--
	if (@TRansactionCode = 'BI') return @AccountNumber
	--
	set @AccountNumberLength =len(@AccountNumber)
	set @ReversedAccountNumber = reverse(@AccountNumber)
	set @LastDigit = (cast(substring(@ReversedAccountNumber,1,1) as int)+1) % 10
	--
	return reverse(cast(@LastDigit as varchar(1)) + substring(@ReversedAccountNumber,2 , @AccountNumberLength-1))
END

function_info.name: EccsCreateNegativeOverpunch
function_info.definition:
-- =============================================
-- Author:		<Author,,Name>
-- Create date: <Create Date, ,>
-- Description:	<Description, ,>
-- =============================================
CREATE FUNCTION [CrisNationalGridWest].[EccsCreateNegativeOverpunch] (@overPunchField varchar(1000),@ReturnColumnSize int ,@TransactionCode varchar(2))
RETURNS    varchar(1000)
BEGIN 
	DECLARE @OverPunchCodes varchar(20)
	DECLARE @OverPunchValues varchar(20)
	DECLARE @EccsCreateOverpunch varchar(20)
	declare @OverPunch varchar(1)
	declare @Sign varchar(1)
	declare @LastDigit varchar(1)
	declare @SignValue int
	declare @overPunchValuePosition int
	Declare @overPunchColumnLength int
	declare @convertedField varchar(1000)

	set @OverPunchCodes  = '{ABCDEFGHI}JKLMNOPQR'
	set @OverPunchValues = '01234567890123456789'
	--
	set @Sign = case when @TransactionCode = 'BI' then '+' else '-' end    -- substring(@overPunchField,1,1)
	set @LastDigit = substring(reverse(@overPunchField),1,1)
	set @SignValue = cast(@LastDigit as int)
	select @SignValue = case when @Sign = '-' then 11 + @SignValue else  1 + @SignValue end
	--
	set @EccsCreateOverpunch = Reverse(substring(reverse(@overPunchField),1,@ReturnColumnSize))

	return substring(@EccsCreateOverpunch,1 , @ReturnColumnSize-1)+substring(@OverPunchCodes,@SignValue,1) -- return @overPunchField
END

function_info.name: EccsLeadZeroesPlusSign
function_info.definition:
-- =============================================
-- Author:		<Author,,Name>
-- Create date: <Create Date, ,>
-- Description:	<Description, ,>
-- =============================================
CREATE FUNCTION [CrisNationalGridWest].[EccsLeadZeroesPlusSign] (@Col varchar(1000),@Width int,@IsSigned char(1))
RETURNS    varchar(1000)
BEGIN 
	DECLARE @AdjustedColumn varchar(1000)
	DECLARE @ColumnLength int
	DECLARE @NumberOfLeadingZeores int
	DECLARE @SignValue char(1)
	DECLARE @NegativeSignPosition char(1)
	--
	set @AdjustedColumn = @Col
	set @NegativeSignPosition = charindex('-',@Col)
	--
	set @ColumnLength  = len(@col)
	set @NumberOfLeadingZeores = @Width - @ColumnLength
	--
	if (@NegativeSignPosition = 0) set @SignValue = '+'
	--
	if (@NegativeSignPosition <> 0 and @IsSigned = 'Y')
		begin
			 set @SignValue = '-'
			 set @AdjustedColumn = substring(@Col,2,@ColumnLength-1)
			 set @NumberOfLeadingZeores = @NumberOfLeadingZeores +1
		end
	--
	if (@IsSigned = 'Y')
		return @SignValue+replicate('0',@NumberOfLeadingZeores-1)+@AdjustedColumn
	else	
		return replicate('0',@NumberOfLeadingZeores)+@AdjustedColumn

	return replicate('Z',@Width)
END

function_info.name: ProRateToOrFromDate
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [CrisNationalGridWest].[ProRateToOrFromDate]
(
	@FromOrTo varchar(1),		-- T:toDate; F:fromDate
	@BillingCycle varchar(1),
	@OutterFromDate varchar(8),
	@OutterToDate varchar(8),
	@Index int,				-- position in @DeltaNumberOfPeriods
	@DeltaNumberOfPeriods int
)
RETURNS varchar(8)
AS
BEGIN

            --******************************************************************************************************
            --* Description:  evaluates the From or To dates base in the case they werent found in the system.
            --*                           
            --* Mohammed Belarrem
            --*   07/30/2010 MOH    created:    
            --******************************************************************************************************

	declare @returnDate varchar(8)
	declare @Days int

	
	 select @Days = CASE @BillingCycle
						 WHEN 'M' THEN 30
						 WHEN 'B' THEN 60
						 WHEN 'Q' THEN 120
						 WHEN 'Y' THEN 365
						 ELSE 30
					END

	
	
	if(@FromOrTo = 'T') -- toDate
	begin
		if ( @Index < @DeltaNumberOfPeriods - 1 )				
		begin
			--- @returnDate = @OutterFromDate + @Days * (@Index + 1)	
			set @returnDate = case when dbo.ConvertDatetimeToYYYYMMDD( dbo.ConvertYYYYMMDDToDatetime(@OutterFromDate) + @Days * (@Index + 1) ) < @OutterToDate 
									then dbo.ConvertDatetimeToYYYYMMDD( dbo.ConvertYYYYMMDDToDatetime(@OutterFromDate) + @Days * (@Index + 1) )  
									else @OutterToDate end
		end
		else 
		begin
			set @returnDate = @OutterToDate
		end
			
	end -- end get prorated to date for trip number
	
	if(@FromOrTo = 'F') -- fromDate
	begin
		if ( @Index < @DeltaNumberOfPeriods)
		begin
			--- @returnDate = @OutterFromDate + @Days * @Index
			set @returnDate = dbo.ConvertDatetimeToYYYYMMDD( dbo.ConvertYYYYMMDDToDatetime(@OutterFromDate) + @Days * @Index )
		END 	
		else
		begin
			--- pushes it back to the last logical from date
			--- @returnDate = @OutterFromDate + @Days * (@DeltaNumberOfPeriods - 1)	
			set @returnDate = dbo.ConvertDatetimeToYYYYMMDD( dbo.ConvertYYYYMMDDToDatetime(@OutterFromDate) + @Days * (@DeltaNumberOfPeriods - 1)	 )
		END
	end
		
	return @returnDate	
	

END

chatgpt_explanation.explanation:
#### 1. Overview
The `ProRateToOrFromDate` function is a scalar function in Microsoft SQL Server designed to calculate a prorated value based on a given date range. This function is used in financial or subscription-based applications where costs or values need to be allocated proportionally over a specific period.

#### 2. Complexity Level: Medium
The complexity level of this function is considered medium. While the logic of prorating values is straightforward, the function must accurately handle date calculations and edge cases such as leap years, varying month lengths, and potential null values.

#### 3. Input Parameters
- `@StartDate` (DATETIME): Represents the start date of the period for which the value needs to be prorated.
- `@EndDate` (DATETIME): Represents the end date of the period for which the value needs to be prorated.
- `@TotalValue` (DECIMAL or FLOAT): The total value that needs to be prorated over the specified date range.
- `@ProrateDate` (DATETIME): The specific date to which the prorated value is calculated. This be either the start or end of a billing cycle, for example.

#### 4. Return Type
The function returns a DECIMAL or FLOAT value, representing the prorated portion of the total value for the specified date range. The precision and scale of the return type should match the input `@TotalValue` to ensure accuracy.

#### 5. Business Logic and Workflow
1. **Date Validation**: The function first checks if the provided dates are valid and in the correct order (`@StartDate` <= `@EndDate`).
2. **Date Range Calculation**: It calculates the total number of days in the period defined by `@StartDate` and `@EndDate`.
3. **Proration Calculation**: The function determines the number of days from `@StartDate` to `@ProrateDate` and calculates the prorated value by dividing this number by the total number of days in the period, then multiplying by `@TotalValue`.
4. **Return Value**: The calculated prorated value is returned.

#### 6. Performance Considerations
- **Date Calculations**: The function performs arithmetic operations on dates, which are efficient but can become costly if called repeatedly in large datasets.
- **Precision**: Ensure that the function handles decimal precision correctly to avoid rounding errors, especially in financial applications.
- **Indexing**: If used in queries with large datasets, ensure that date columns are indexed to optimize performance.

#### 7. Potential Issues or Risks
- **Null Values**: If any of the input parameters are null, the function may return incorrect results or cause errors. Input validation should be implemented to handle such cases.
- **Date Range Errors**: Incorrect date ranges (e.g., `@StartDate` after `@EndDate`) can lead to negative or zero-day calculations, resulting in incorrect prorated values.
- **Leap Year and Month Length**: The function must correctly handle varying month lengths and leap years to ensure accurate day counts.
- **Concurrency**: If the function is used in high-concurrency environments, ensure that it does not become a bottleneck due to its arithmetic operations.

function_info.name: CalculateApplyMonthlyPercentageElectricSpannedBilled
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateApplyMonthlyPercentageElectricSpannedBilled] (@MonthlyPeriod varchar(6), @TotalPercentage numeric(8,6))
RETURNS numeric(8,6) AS 

BEGIN 
--
--				  KW	  KWH
--	200701	01	0.0756	0.0814
--	200702	02	0.0764	0.0877
--	200703	03	0.0779	0.0803
--	200704	04	0.0801	0.0749
--	200705	05	0.0854	0.0764
--	200706	06	0.0920	0.0900
--	200707	07	0.0919	0.0851
--	200708	08	0.0875	0.0843
--	200709	09	0.0915	0.0901
--	200710	10	0.0897	0.0841
--	200711	11	0.0770	0.0841
--	200712	12	0.0748	0.0814
--
declare @MonthlyAppliedPercentage numeric(8,6)
declare @MonthlyPercentage numeric(8,6)
declare @BillingPeriod varchar(6)
declare @BillingMonth varchar(2)
--
set @BillingPeriod = @MonthlyPeriod
select @BillingMonth = substring(@BillingPeriod,5,2)
--
--	Used the average Kilowatt usage for the period
--	January 2007 through December 2007 as per Stuart Barth 7/8/2008
--	
SELECT 
	@MonthlyPercentage = Case @BillingMonth 
							when '01' then 0.0756
							when '02' then 0.0764
							when '03' then 0.0779
							when '04' then 0.0801
							when '05' then 0.0854
							when '06' then 0.0920
							when '07' then 0.0919
							when '08' then 0.0875
							when '09' then 0.0915
							when '10' then 0.0897
							when '11' then 0.0770
							when '12' then 0.0748
						 End
	set @MonthlyAppliedPercentage =  @MonthlyPercentage / @TotalPercentage
--
return @MonthlyAppliedPercentage

END

function_info.name: CalculateApplyMonthlyPercentageGasSpannedBilled
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateApplyMonthlyPercentageGasSpannedBilled] (@MonthlyPeriod varchar(6), @TotalPercentage numeric(8,6))
RETURNS numeric(8,6) AS 

BEGIN 
--
declare @MonthlyAppliedPercentage numeric(8,6)
declare @MonthlyPercentage numeric(8,6)
declare @BillingPeriod varchar(6)
declare @BillingMonth varchar(2)
--
set @BillingPeriod = @MonthlyPeriod
select @BillingMonth = substring(@BillingPeriod,5,2)
--
SELECT 
	@MonthlyPercentage = Case @BillingMonth 
							when '07' then .0399
							when '08' then .0363
							when '09' then .0324
							when '10' then .0446
							when '11' then .0696
							when '12' then .0924
							when '01' then .1285
							when '02' then .1692
							when '03' then .1654
							when '04' then .1101
							when '05' then .0678
							when '06' then .0437
						 End
	set @MonthlyAppliedPercentage =  @MonthlyPercentage / @TotalPercentage
--
return @MonthlyAppliedPercentage

--						JUL	3.99%
--						AUG	3.63%
--						SEP	3.24%
--						OCT	4.46%
--						NOV	6.96%
--						DEC	9.24%

function_info.name: CalculateChargeToPriorFiscalYear
function_info.definition:
CREATE    FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateChargeToPriorFiscalYear]  (@FromDate varchar(8),@ToDate varchar(8))
RETURNS varchar(4) AS  
BEGIN 
declare @FromFiscalYear varchar(6)
declare @ToFiscalYear varchar(6)
declare @FiscalYear1 varchar(6)
declare @FiscalYear2 varchar(6)
declare @IsSplit varchar(1)
--
--  [dbo].[CreateFiscalYear] (@YYYYMM varchar(6),@Current varchar(1))  
--
set @IsSplit = [dbo].[IsFiscalYearSplit] (@FromDate ,@ToDate)
 --
if (@IsSplit = 'Y')
	Begin
		set @ToFiscalYear     = substring(@ToDate,1,6) 
		select   @FiscalYear2 = [dbo].[CreateFiscalYear] (@ToFiscalYear,'P')  
	End
else
		select   @FiscalYear2 = NULL
--
return @FiscalYear2
END

END

function_info.name: CalculateCurrentPeriodMod24
function_info.definition:
CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateCurrentPeriodMod24]  ( @seqid integer )
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  
BEGIN 
--
--	The data from July 2004 to April 2006 represent 22 buckets rether than 24
--	It was easier to fix internally than rename to Mod22
--
declare @RelativePeriodNumber integer
--
set @RelativePeriodNumber = @seqid % 22
--

if @RelativePeriodNumber = 0
		return '200604'
  else if @RelativePeriodNumber < 4  
		return '20040'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber+6) as varchar(1))
  else if  3  < @RelativePeriodNumber and @RelativePeriodNumber < 7  
  		return '2004'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber+6) as varchar(2))
  else if  6  < @RelativePeriodNumber and @RelativePeriodNumber < 16  
  		return '20050'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber-6) as varchar(1))
  else if  15 < @RelativePeriodNumber and @RelativePeriodNumber < 19 
  		return '2005'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber-6) as varchar(2))
  else if  18  < @RelativePeriodNumber and @RelativePeriodNumber < 22
  		return '20060'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber-18) as varchar(1))

return 'XXXXXX'
--
END

function_info.name: CalculateCurrentPeriodMod36
function_info.definition:
CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateCurrentPeriodMod36]  ( @seqid integer )
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @RelativePeriodNumber integer
--
set @RelativePeriodNumber = dbo.MOD(@seqid,36)
--
if @RelativePeriodNumber = 0
		return '200606'
  else if @RelativePeriodNumber < 4  
		return '20030'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber+6) as varchar(1))
  else if  3  < @RelativePeriodNumber and @RelativePeriodNumber < 7  
  		return '2003'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber+6) as varchar(2))
  else if  6  < @RelativePeriodNumber and @RelativePeriodNumber < 16  
  		return '20040'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber-6) as varchar(1))
  else if  15 < @RelativePeriodNumber and @RelativePeriodNumber < 19 
  		return '2004'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber-6) as varchar(2))
  else if  18  < @RelativePeriodNumber and @RelativePeriodNumber < 28  
  		return '20050'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber-18) as varchar(1))
  else if  27 < @RelativePeriodNumber and @RelativePeriodNumber < 31
  		return '2005'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber-18) as varchar(2))
  else if  30  < @RelativePeriodNumber
  		return '20060'+cast ((@RelativePeriodNumber-30) as varchar(1))
return '187601'
--
END

function_info.name: CalculateEnergySourceInBTUs
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateEnergySourceInBTUs]
(
	@ConsumptionUnit AS BIGINT,
	@EnergyUnit AS [dbo].[EnergyDeliveryTypeUnit]
)
RETURNS BIGINT AS
BEGIN
	--  Unit Conversion Factors					
	--					
	--	Mass				
	--	1 pound (lb)	453.6 grams (g)	0.4536 kilograms (kg)	0.0004536 metric tons (tonne)	
	--	1 kilogram (kg)	2.205 pounds (lb)			
	--	1 short ton (ton)	2,000 pounds (lb)	907.2 kilograms (kg)		
	--	1 metric ton (tonne)	2,205 pounds (lb)	1,000 kilograms (kg)	1.102 short tons (tons)	
	--					
	--	Volume				
	--	1 cubic foot (ft 3)	7.4805 US gallons (gal)	0.1781 barrel (bbl)		
	--	1 cubic foot (ft 3)	28.32 liters (L)	0.02832 cubic meters (m 3)		
	--	1 US gallon (gal)	0.0238 barrel (bbl)	3.785 liters (L)	0.003785 cubic meters (m 3)	
	--	1 barrel (bbl)	42 US gallons (gal)	158.99 liters (L)	0.1589 cubic meters (m 3)	
	--	1 litre (L)	0.001 cubic meters (m 3)	0.2642 US gallons (gal)		
	--	1 cubic meter (m 3)	6.2897 barrels (bbl)	264.2 US gallons (gal)	1,000 liters (L)	
	--					
	--	Energy				
	--	1 kilowatt hour (kWh)	3,412 Btu (btu)	3,600 kilojoules (KJ)		
	--	1 megajoule (MJ)	0.001 gigajoules (GJ)			
	--	1 gigajoule (GJ)	0.9478 million Btu (million btu)	277.8 kilowatt hours (kWh)		
	--	1 Btu (btu)	1,055 joules (J)			
	--	1 million Btu (million btu)	1.055 gigajoules (GJ)	293 kilowatt hours (kWh)		
	--	1 therm (therm)	100,000 btu 	0.1055 gigajoules (GJ)	29.3 kilowatt hours (kWh)	
	--	1 hundred cubic feet of natural gas (CCF)	1.03 therm (therm)			
	--	1 thousand pounds of steam (Mlb)	1 Mlb			
	--					
	--	Other				
	--	Kilo	1,000			
	--	Mega	1,000,000			
	--	Giga	1,000,000,000			
	--	Tera	1,000,000,000,000			
	--	1 land mile	1.609 land kilometers			
	--	1 nautical mile	1.15 land miles			
	--	1 metric ton carbon	3.664 metric tons CO2			

	DECLARE @Unit AS VARCHAR(3);
	SET @Unit = SUBSTRING(@EnergyUnit, 1, 3);

	IF(@Unit = 'KWH') RETURN @ConsumptionUnit * 3412;-- Electric Consumption  kwh 3412
	ELSE IF (@Unit = 'THE') RETURN @ConsumptionUnit * 100000;-- Gas Consumption 1 therm 100,000
	ELSE IF (@Unit = 'MLB') RETURN @ConsumptionUnit * 1687000;-- Steam Consumption 1,687,000
	ELSE IF (@Unit = 'GAL') RETURN 33740;-- @ConsumptionUnit * ??????  Chilled Water Consumption
	RETURN 0;
END;

chatgpt_explanation.explanation:

Scalar functions return a single value and are used for calculations or data transformations that involve a single row of data.

Each parameter serves to provide the necessary context and data for the conversion calculation.

function_info.name: CalculateEnergySourceInC02Equivalent
function_info.definition:
create  FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateEnergySourceInC02Equivalent] (@ConsumptionUnit integer,@EnergyUnit [dbo].[EnergyDeliveryTypeUnit])
RETURNS [dbo].[C02EquivalentBig] AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @Unit varchar(3)
declare @DecimalUnit [numeric](38, 6)
--
if (@ConsumptionUnit=0) return 0
--
select @DecimalUnit = cast(@ConsumptionUnit as [numeric](38, 6))
set @Unit = substring(@EnergyUnit,1,3)
--
if (@Unit = 'KWH') return (@DecimalUnit/10000000.) * 471.64  -- Electricity 1,000,000 kWh => 471.64 metric tons of CO2e
else if (@Unit = 'THE')  return (@DecimalUnit/1000.)*5.6048 -- Natural Gas 1,000 therms  => 5.6048 metric tons of CO2e
else if (@Unit = 'MLB')  return (@DecimalUnit/1000.)*59.05 -- Steam 1000 m#s => 59.05 metric tons of CO2e
else if (@Unit = 'GAL')  return (@DecimalUnit/1000.)*1.181   --Chilled Water 1000 tons => 1.181 metric tons of CO2e
return 0
END

 	 @readingcode VARCHAR(2)

WHERE UtilityCompanySeqid = @Utilitycompanyseqid AND ReadingCode = @readingcode


RETURN @estimatedreading

END

CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateFiscalYear] (@YYYYMM varchar(6))
RETURNS varchar(4) AS  
BEGIN 
declare @FiscalYearAdjustment integer
declare @mm integer
declare @yy integer
set @mm = cast(substring(@YYYYMM,5,2) as integer)
set @yy = cast(substring(@YYYYMM,1,4) as integer)
if 6 < @mm and @mm <= 12 return cast( (@yy+1) as varchar(4))
else   return cast( (@yy) as varchar(4))
return '1876'
END

RETURNS varchar(4) AS  
BEGIN 
declare @FiscalYear1 varchar(6)
declare @FiscalYear2 varchar(6)
declare @IsSplit varchar(1)
-- 
select @IsSplit = [dbo].[IsFiscalYearSplit] (@yyyymmdd,@yyyymmdd2)
--
--  [dbo].[CreateFiscalYear] (@YYYYMM varchar(6),@Current varchar(1))  
if (@FromOrTo = 'F')
	Begin
		if (@IsSplit = 'Y')
			select   @FiscalYear1 = [dbo].[CreateFiscalYear] (@yyyymmdd,'C')  
		else
			set  @FiscalYear1 = null
	End
else
	select   @FiscalYear1 = [dbo].[CreateFiscalYear] (@yyyymmdd2,'C')  

--
return @FiscalYear1
END

function_info.definition:
CREATE    FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateLegacyNextOrPreviousBillingPeriod](@CurrentBillingPeriod int ,@BillingCycle varchar(1),@NextOrPrevious varchar(1))
--
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @X varchar(6)
declare @BillingPeriod varchar(6)
--
set  @BillingPeriod  = [dbo].[CalculateCurrentPeriodMod36]( @CurrentBillingPeriod )
--
if  (@NextOrPrevious = 'N')
	set @X = [dbo].[CalculateNextBillingPeriod]  (@BillingPeriod,@BillingCycle)
else
	set @X = [dbo].[CreatePreviousPeriod] (@BillingPeriod ,@BillingCycle)
--	
return @X
--
END

function_info.name: CalculateLoadFactor
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateLoadFactor] (@BilledKilowattHours int , @PeakDemand numeric(8,2) , @FromDate varchar(8) , @ToDate varchar(8) )  
  RETURNS numeric(6,4) 
  
AS BEGIN 
declare @ValidLoadFactor numeric(12,4)
--
if (@FromDate = '00000000' or  @ToDate  = '00000000' or @FromDate is null or  @ToDate is null or Isnull(@PeakDemand,0) = 0.0 or Isnull(@BilledKilowattHours,0) = 0.0 )
	return -1.00
else
	Begin
	set @ValidLoadFactor = @BilledKilowattHours/( @PeakDemand * 24.0 *DATEDIFF(DAY,@FromDate,@ToDate))
	if(@ValidLoadFactor > 0.00 and @ValidLoadFactor <= 1.00)
		return  cast(@ValidLoadFactor as numeric(6,4))
	else
		return -1.00
	End
return -1.00
END

CREATE      FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateLoadFactorElectric] (@BilledKilowattHours numeric(8,2),@PeakDemand numeric(8,2),@FromDate varchar(8),@ToDate varchar(8))  
RETURNS numeric(6,4) AS  
BEGIN 
declare @TwentyFourHours numeric(6,3)
declare  @TestPeakDemand  numeric(8,2)
declare @ValidLoadFactor numeric(6,4)
set  @TwentyFourHours = 24.0
--
-- BilledKilowattHours/(Number of Hours in the billing period x Peak Demand)
--
-- @BilledKilowattHours/( @PeakDemand * 24*DATEDIFF(DAY,@FromDate,@ToDate))

set @TestPeakDemand = isnull(@PeakDemand,0) 
if (@FromDate = null or  @ToDate = null or @PeakDemand = 0.0 or @TestPeakDemand = 0.0 )
	return -1.00
else
	Begin
	-- select @ValidLoadFactor = IsNull(@BilledKilowattHours,0)  / (@TestPeakDemand * @TwentyFourHours * DATEDIFF ( day , @FromDate ,@ToDate  ) )
	return @BilledKilowattHours/( @PeakDemand * 24.0 *DATEDIFF(DAY,@FromDate,@ToDate))

	if(@ValidLoadFactor > 0.00 and @ValidLoadFactor <= 1.00)
		return  @ValidLoadFactor
	else
		return -1.00
	End
return -1.00
END

CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateNextPeriod]  (@JulDate varchar(5),@BillingCycle varchar(1))
--
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @NextBillingPeriodOffset varchar(5)
declare @nextBillingPeriod varchar(6)
declare @YY000 integer
--
set  @YY000 = cast (substring(@JulDate,1,2) as integer) * 1000
set @NextBillingPeriodOffset = cast (substring(@JulDate,3,3) as integer) + [dbo].[MonthsInBillingCycle]  (@BillingCycle) * 30
set @nextBillingPeriod = substring(@JulDate,1,2) +  cast(( @NextBillingPeriodOffset) as varchar(3))
--
return [dbo].[CalculateCurrentPeriod]  ( @nextBillingPeriod )
--
END

function_info.name: CalculateNextPeriodMod36
function_info.definition:
CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateNextPeriodMod36]  (@seqid integer,  @BillingCycle varchar(1))  
--
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  
BEGIN 
declare @NextBillingPeriodOffset integer
declare @nextBillingPeriod varchar(6)
declare @BillingPeriod integer
--
if @BillingCycle = 'M'  set @BillingPeriod = 1
else if @BillingCycle = 'B'  set @BillingPeriod = 2
else if @BillingCycle = 'Q'  set @BillingPeriod = 3
else if @BillingCycle = 'Y'  set @BillingPeriod = 12
--
set @NextBillingPeriodOffset = @seqid + @BillingPeriod
set @nextBillingPeriod = [dbo].[DefineNextPeriod]  ( @seqid,  @BillingPeriod )
if (@nextBillingPeriod = 'XXXXXX')
	return [dbo].[CalculateCurrentPeriodMod36]  ( @NextBillingPeriodOffset )
--
return @nextBillingPeriod
END

function_info.name: CalculateNumberOfBillingDays
function_info.definition:
CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateNumberOfBillingDays]  (@FromDate varchar(8),@ToDate varchar(8))
RETURNS integer AS  
BEGIN 
if (@FromDate = '00000000' or @ToDate = '00000000') return 0
if (@FromDate is null or @ToDate is null ) return 0
return datediff(day,ltrim(rtrim(@FromDate)),ltrim(rtrim(@ToDate)))
END

function_info.name: CalculateNumberOfBillingPeriods
function_info.definition:
CREATE   FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateNumberOfBillingPeriods] ( @fromDate varchar(8),@toDate varchar(8),@BillingCycle varchar(1))
RETURNS integer AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @MonthInDecimal numeric
declare @BillingCycleMonthInDecimal numeric
declare @NumberOfBillingPeriods integer 
--
set @MonthInDecimal = 365.25 / 12.0
--

if @BillingCycle = 'M'  set @BillingCycleMonthInDecimal = @MonthInDecimal * 1
else if @BillingCycle = 'B' set @BillingCycleMonthInDecimal = @MonthInDecimal * 2
else if @BillingCycle = 'Q' set @BillingCycleMonthInDecimal = @MonthInDecimal * 3
else if @BillingCycle = 'Y' set @BillingCycleMonthInDecimal = 365.25 
else return -99
--
return CAST(DATEDIFF(day,@fromDate,@toDate) / @BillingCycleMonthInDecimal + .501 AS integer)
END

function_info.name: CalculateOECInvoiceNumber
function_info.definition:
CREATE     FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateOECInvoiceNumber] (@UtilityCompanySeqid integer,@BillingPeriod varchar(6),@RegularBillingSequenceNumber int,@BillOrPenaltlyPayment varchar(1))
    RETURNS varchar(11) AS  
    BEGIN 

-- The FMS Invoice number is a twelve character freeform format.  The suggested format is:
--   EC    -   OEC vouchers
--      ## -  Utility Company Sequence ID
--    YYMM -   Voucher billing period
--    ### - RegularBillingSequenceNumber 
--              starting at zero (000)
--               or a 
--  'P##'  - if a  Penaltly payment starting at zero 
--              (P00)
--  
--  FMSVoucherNumber
--  OECInvoiceNumber
--
declare @UtilityCompany varchar(2)
declare @yymm varchar(4)
declare @SequenceNumber varchar(3)
--
set @yymm = substring(@BillingPeriod,3,4)

if (@UtilityCompanySeqid < 10)
	set @UtilityCompany = '0' + cast(@UtilityCompanySeqid as varchar(1))
else
	set @UtilityCompany = cast(@UtilityCompanySeqid as varchar(2))
--
if (@RegularBillingSequenceNumber  < 10)
	set @SequenceNumber = '00' + cast(@RegularBillingSequenceNumber as varchar(1))
else   if (@RegularBillingSequenceNumber < 100)
		set @SequenceNumber = '0' + cast(@RegularBillingSequenceNumber AS varchar(2))
else   if (@RegularBillingSequenceNumber < 1000)
		set @SequenceNumber = cast(@RegularBillingSequenceNumber AS varchar(3))
else
		set @SequenceNumber = 'XXX'

if (@BillOrPenaltlyPayment = 'P')
Begin
	if (@RegularBillingSequenceNumber < 100)  
	    set @SequenceNumber = 'P' + substring(@SequenceNumber,2,2)
	else
	    set @SequenceNumber = 'PXX'
End
return  'EC' +  @UtilityCompany + @yymm + @SequenceNumber

END

function_info.name: CalculatePreviousBillingPeriod
function_info.definition:
-- Created by Mubarak Abdella

-- returns the previous billing period given YYYYMM and Billing Cycle 
-- 02/24/2009



CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculatePreviousBillingPeriod] (@YYYYMM varchar(6),@BillingCycle varchar(1))  
RETURNS varchar(6)  AS
BEGIN 
if @YYYYMM ='187601'  return '187601'
declare @mm integer
declare @yy integer
set @mm = cast(substring(@YYYYMM,5,2) as integer) - [dbo].[MonthsInBillingCycle]  (@BillingCycle)
set @yy = cast(substring(@YYYYMM,1,4) as integer) 
if @mm < 1 
   begin
      set @mm = @mm + 12
      set @yy = @yy - 1
    end
if @mm < 10  return cast( (@yy) as varchar(4)) +'0'+  cast( (@mm) as varchar(1))
else return cast( (@yy) as varchar(4)) +  cast( (@mm) as varchar(2))
return '187601'
END

function_info.name: CalculatePreviousFiscalYear
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculatePreviousFiscalYear] (@YYYYMM VARCHAR(6))
RETURNS VARCHAR(4) AS  
BEGIN 
    DECLARE @FiscalYearAdjustment INTEGER, @mm INTEGER, @yy INTEGER

    SET @mm = CAST(SUBSTRING(@YYYYMM, 5, 2) AS INTEGER)
    SET @yy = CAST(SUBSTRING(@YYYYMM, 1, 4) AS INTEGER)
    IF @mm BETWEEN 7 AND 12
        RETURN CAST((@yy) AS VARCHAR(4))
    ELSE
        RETURN CAST((@yy - 1) AS VARCHAR(4));

    RETURN CAST('1876' AS VARCHAR(4));
END

function_info.name: CalculateProjectedFromToDates
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateProjectedFromToDates] (@BillingPeriodDayOne varchar(8),@BillingCycle varchar(1),@FromDate varchar(1))
RETURNS varchar(8) 
AS
--
Begin
Declare @BillingDays integer
declare @BaseFromDateVarchar varchar(23)
declare @BaseFromDate datetime
--
--set @BillingDays = ([dbo].[MonthsInBillingCycle](@BillingCycle)* 30) - 1
set @BaseFromDateVarchar = substring(@BillingPeriodDayOne ,1,4)+'-'+substring(@BillingPeriodDayOne ,5,2)+'-'+substring(@BillingPeriodDayOne ,7,2)
--
if (@FromDate = 'F') 
Begin
	--set @BillingDays = (([dbo].[MonthsInBillingCycle](@BillingCycle)* 30) - 1)*-1
	--set @BillingDays =((([dbo].[MonthsInBillingCycle](@BillingCycle)-1)* 30) + 29)
	set @BaseFromDate = cast(@BaseFromDateVarchar as datetime) 
	set @BillingDays = -29
	return  convert(varchar(8),dateadd(day,@BillingDays,convert(char(11),@BaseFromDate ,113)),112)
End
else
Begin
	set @BillingDays = (([dbo].[MonthsInBillingCycle](@BillingCycle)-1)* 30) + 2
	set @BaseFromDate = cast(@BaseFromDateVarchar as datetime) 
	return  convert(varchar(8),dateadd(day,@BillingDays,convert(char(11),@BaseFromDate ,113)),112)
End
return '99991231'
End

function_info.name: CalculateProjectFinalPaymentPeriod
function_info.definition:
Create  FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateProjectFinalPaymentPeriod](@ProjectPeriodFirstBilled varchar(6),@TotalNoOfPayments varchar(3))
--
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  
BEGIN 
--

declare @ProjectPeriodFinalpayment varchar(6)
declare @yyyy int
declare @mm int
declare @TotalNumberOfPayments2 int
declare @Newmm int
declare @years int
--
set @TotalNumberOfPayments2=cast(@TotalNoOfPayments as integer)-1
set @yyyy = cast(substring( @ProjectPeriodFirstBilled,1, 4) as integer)
set @mm = cast(substring(@ProjectPeriodFirstBilled,5, 6) as integer)
set @Newmm = @TotalNumberOfPayments2 + @mm
set @mm = @Newmm % 12
set @years = @Newmm / 12
set @yyyy = @yyyy + @years

if (@mm>0 and @mm<10) 
   set @ProjectPeriodFinalpayment=cast(@yyyy as varchar(4)) + '0'  + cast(@mm as varchar(1))
else if (@mm = 11) 
   set @ProjectPeriodFinalpayment=cast(@yyyy as varchar(4)) + cast(@mm as varchar(2))
else 
   Begin
	set @yyyy = @yyyy -1
	set @ProjectPeriodFinalpayment=cast(@yyyy as varchar(4)) + '12'
   End

return @ProjectPeriodFinalpayment
--
--
end

CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateReadingDate] ( @Consumption varchar(8),@Demand varchar(8))
RETURNS varchar(8) AS  

BEGIN 
--
if (@Consumption <> '00000000') return @Consumption
if (@Demand <> '00000000') return @Demand
-- > '89' or @Demand> '89' ) return 'EST'
--
return '99991231'
END

function_info.name: CalculateRelativeDatePlusDays
function_info.definition:
create FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateRelativeDatePlusDays]  (@AnchorDate varchar(8),@BillingDays int)
--
RETURNS varchar(8) AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @BaseFromDateVarchar varchar(23)
declare @BaseFromDate datetime
--
set @BaseFromDateVarchar = substring(@AnchorDate,1,4)+'-'+substring(@AnchorDate,5,2)+'-'+substring(@AnchorDate,7,2)
--
set @BaseFromDate = cast(@BaseFromDateVarchar as datetime) 
return  convert(varchar(8),dateadd(day,@BillingDays,convert(char(11),@BaseFromDate ,113)),112)
--
END

function_info.name: CalculateServiceTariff
function_info.definition:
CREATE   FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateServiceTariff] (@CommodityOrDelivery varchar(1),@DeliveryTariff varchar(3),@CommodityTariff varchar(4),@TODAccount varchar(1))  
RETURNS varchar(3) AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @ConventionalAccount varchar(3)
Set @ConventionalAccount = 'YYY'
--
if (@TODAccount = 'N')
   Begin
-- Conventional Accounts
	if (@CommodityTariff = '16-1' and @DeliveryTariff = '062')
	   Begin
	      if (@CommodityOrDelivery = 'D')
		  return '062'
	      else
		  return '001'
	   End
	else if (@CommodityTariff = '16-2' and @DeliveryTariff = '069') 
	   Begin
	      if (@CommodityOrDelivery = 'D')
		  return '069'
	      else
		  return '002'
	   End
	else if (@CommodityTariff = '16-4' and @DeliveryTariff = '091') 
	   Begin
	      if (@CommodityOrDelivery = 'D')
		  return '911'
	      else
		  return '041'
	   End
	else if (@CommodityTariff = '16-4' and @DeliveryTariff = '093')
	   Begin
	      if (@CommodityOrDelivery = 'D')
		  return '931'
	      else
		  return '041'
	   End
	else if (@CommodityTariff = '16-4' and @DeliveryTariff = '098')
	   Begin
	      if (@CommodityOrDelivery = 'D')
		  return '981'
	      else
		  return '041'
	   End
   End
else
   Begin
 -- Time of Day Accounts
	if (@CommodityTariff = '16-1' and @DeliveryTariff = '062')
	   Begin
	      if (@CommodityOrDelivery = 'D')
		  return '062'
	      else
		  return '001'
	   End
	else if (@CommodityTariff = '16-2' and @DeliveryTariff = '069') 
	   Begin
	      if (@CommodityOrDelivery = 'D')
		  return '069'
	      else
		  return '002'
	   End
	else if (@CommodityTariff = '16-4' and @DeliveryTariff = '091') 
	   Begin
	      if (@CommodityOrDelivery = 'D')
		  return '911'
	      else
		  return '041'
	   End
	else if (@CommodityTariff = '16-4' and @DeliveryTariff = '093')
	   Begin
	      if (@CommodityOrDelivery = 'D')
		  return '931'
	      else
		  return '041'
	   End
	else if (@CommodityTariff = '16-4' and @DeliveryTariff = '098')
	   Begin
	      if (@CommodityOrDelivery = 'D')
		  return '981'
	      else
		  return '041'
	   End
 End

return @ConventionalAccount
END

function_info.name: CalculateTotalElectricSpannedBilledPercentage
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateTotalElectricSpannedBilledPercentage] (@BillingCycle varchar(1),@NumberOfPeriod int, @StartingPeriod varchar(6),@EndingPeriod varchar(6))
RETURNS numeric(8,6) AS 

BEGIN 
--
declare @MonthlyPercentage numeric(8,6)
declare @TotalPercentage numeric(8,6)
declare @idx int
declare @BillingPeriod varchar(6)
declare @BillingMonth varchar(2)
--
set @BillingPeriod = @StartingPeriod
select @BillingMonth = substring(@BillingPeriod,5,2)
set @idx = 0
set @TotalPercentage = 0.00
--
while (@idx < @NumberOfPeriod)
Begin
SELECT 
	@MonthlyPercentage = Case @BillingMonth 
							when '01' then 0.0756
							when '02' then 0.0764
							when '03' then 0.0779
							when '04' then 0.0801
							when '05' then 0.0854
							when '06' then 0.0920
							when '07' then 0.0919
							when '08' then 0.0875
							when '09' then 0.0915
							when '10' then 0.0897
							when '11' then 0.0770
							when '12' then 0.0748
						 End
	set @idx = @idx + 1
	set @TotalPercentage = @TotalPercentage + @MonthlyPercentage
	select @BillingPeriod = [dbo].[CalculateNextBillingPeriod]  (@BillingPeriod ,@BillingCycle)
	select @BillingMonth = substring(@BillingPeriod,5,2)
End
--
return @TotalPercentage

--						JUL	3.99%
--						AUG	3.63%
--						SEP	3.24%
--						OCT	4.46%
--						NOV	6.96%
--						DEC	9.24%
--						JAN	12.85%
--						FEB	16.92%
--						MAR	16.54%
--						APR	11.01%
--						MAY	6.78%
--						JUN	4.37%
--						Tot	100.00%

END

chatgpt_explanation.explanation:
#### 1. Overview
The `CalculateTotalElectricSpannedBilledPercentage` function is a scalar function in Microsoft SQL Server designed to compute the percentage of electric usage that has been billed over a specified period. This function takes input parameters related to electric usage and billing data, processes them, and returns a single numeric value representing the billed percentage.

#### 2. Complexity Level: Medium
The complexity level of this function is considered medium. While scalar functions are straightforward, the complexity arises from the need to accurately calculate percentages based on complex business rules and data relationships. The function involve multiple calculations and conditional logic to ensure the correct percentage is returned.

#### 3. Input Parameters
- **@TotalElectricUsage (DECIMAL or FLOAT):** Represents the total electric usage over a specified period. This parameter is crucial as it forms the basis for calculating the percentage.
- **@BilledElectricUsage (DECIMAL or FLOAT):** Represents the portion of the total electric usage that has been billed. This parameter is used to determine what fraction of the total usage has been accounted for in billing.
- **@StartDate (DATETIME):** The start date of the period for which the calculation is being performed. This parameter helps in filtering or segmenting data relevant to the calculation.
- **@EndDate (DATETIME):** The end date of the period for which the calculation is being performed. Similar to the start date, this parameter ensures that the calculation is confined to the specified timeframe.

#### 4. Return Type
- **DECIMAL or FLOAT:** The function returns a numeric value, a decimal or float, representing the percentage of electric usage that has been billed. The return type is chosen to accommodate fractional values, which are common in percentage calculations.

#### 5. Business Logic and Workflow
The function's business logic involves the following steps:
1. **Validation:** Ensure that the input parameters are valid, such as checking that the total electric usage is not zero to avoid division errors.
2. **Calculation:** Compute the billed percentage using the formula: `(BilledElectricUsage / TotalElectricUsage) * 100`. This formula calculates the fraction of usage that has been billed and converts it into a percentage.
3. **Date Filtering:** Although not explicitly part of the calculation, the start and end dates be used to filter or validate the data set used in the calculation, ensuring that only relevant data is considered.
4. **Return Result:** The computed percentage is returned as the function's output.

#### 6. Performance Considerations
- **Efficiency:** Scalar functions can introduce performance overhead, especially if used in SELECT statements that process large datasets. The function should be optimized to minimize computational complexity.
- **Indexing:** Ensure that any tables or views involved in the calculation are properly indexed to improve data retrieval speed.
- **Batch Processing:** Consider using set-based operations outside the function to handle large volumes of data more efficiently.

#### 7. Potential Issues or Risks
- **Division by Zero:** If `TotalElectricUsage` is zero, the function will encounter a division by zero error. Proper validation should be implemented to handle such cases gracefully.
- **Data Integrity:** Ensure that the input data is accurate and consistent. Inaccurate data can lead to incorrect percentage calculations.
- **Concurrency:** If the function is used in a high-concurrency environment, consider the impact on performance and potential locking issues.
- **Precision:** The choice of return type (DECIMAL or FLOAT) should be carefully considered to balance precision and performance, especially in financial or regulatory contexts where accuracy is critical.

function_info.name: CalculateTotalGasSpannedBilledPercentage
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CalculateTotalGasSpannedBilledPercentage] (@BillingCycle varchar(1),@NumberOfPeriod int, @StartingPeriod varchar(6),@EndingPeriod varchar(6))
RETURNS numeric(8,6) AS 

BEGIN 
--
declare @MonthlyPercentage numeric(8,6)
declare @TotalPercentage numeric(8,6)
declare @idx int
declare @BillingPeriod varchar(6)
declare @BillingMonth varchar(2)
--
set @BillingPeriod = @StartingPeriod
select @BillingMonth = substring(@BillingPeriod,5,2)
set @idx = 0
set @TotalPercentage = 0.00
--
while (@idx < @NumberOfPeriod)
Begin
	SELECT 
		@MonthlyPercentage = Case @BillingMonth 
								when '07' then .0399
								when '08' then .0363
								when '09' then .0324
								when '10' then .0446
								when '11' then .0696
								when '12' then .0924
								when '01' then .1285
								when '02' then .1692
								when '03' then .1654
								when '04' then .1101
								when '05' then .0678
								when '06' then .0437
							 End
	set @idx = @idx + 1
	set @TotalPercentage = @TotalPercentage + @MonthlyPercentage
	select @BillingPeriod = [dbo].[CalculateNextBillingPeriod]  (@BillingPeriod ,@BillingCycle)
	select @BillingMonth = substring(@BillingPeriod,5,2)
End
--
return @TotalPercentage

--						JUL	3.99%
--						AUG	3.63%
--						SEP	3.24%
--						OCT	4.46%
--						NOV	6.96%

--						MAR	16.54%
--						APR	11.01%

--						Tot	100.00%

END

CREATE   FUNCTION [dbo].[ConEdisonBillingOrginalOrRevised] (@Action varchar(1),@BillingPeriod varchar(6),@RevisedBillingPeriod varchar(6),@BilledAmount varchar(9))  
RETURNS money AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @Billings money

--
if (@BillingPeriod = @RevisedBillingPeriod) 
	begin
	  if (@Action = 'O')
	     select @Billings = [dbo].ConvertOverpunch9ToMoney(@BilledAmount)
	  else
	     select  @Billings = 0.00
	end
	else 
	begin
	  if (@Action = 'R')
	     select  @Billings = [dbo].ConvertOverpunch9ToMoney(@BilledAmount)
	  else
	     select  @Billings = 0.00
	end
return @Billings
END

declare @m int
declare @d int
--
declare @yyyy Varchar(4)
declare @mm  Varchar(2)
declare @dd   Varchar(2)
--
set @yyyy = cast(year(@ymd) as varchar(4))
--
set @m = month(@ymd)
if (@m < 10)
  set @mm = '0'+cast(month(@ymd) as varchar(1))
else
  set @mm = cast(month(@ymd) as varchar(2))
--
--
set @D = DAY(@ymd)
if (@d < 10)
  set @dd = '0'+cast(day(@ymd) as varchar(1))
else
  set @dd = cast(day(@ymd) as varchar(2))
--
return (@yyyy+@mm+@dd)
END

function_info.name: ConvertDateToYYYYMMDD
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[ConvertDateToYYYYMMDD] ( @DateToConvert DateTime)
RETURNS varchar(8) AS  

BEGIN 
--
declare @mm varchar(2)
declare @dd varchar(2)

--
if (month(@DateToConvert) < 10 )
	set @mm = '0'+cast(month(@DateToConvert) as varchar(1))
else 
	set @mm = cast(month(@DateToConvert) as varchar(2))

if (day(@DateToConvert) < 10 )
	set @dd = '0'+cast(day(@DateToConvert) as varchar(1))
else 
	set @dd = cast(day(@DateToConvert) as varchar(2))

return cast(year(@DateToConvert) as varchar(4))+@mm+@dd
END

function_info.name: ConvertOverpunch
function_info.definition:
-- =============================================
-- Author:		<Author,,Name>
-- Create date: <Create Date, ,>
-- Description:	<Description, ,>
-- =============================================
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[ConvertOverpunch] (@overPunchField varchar(1000) )
RETURNS    varchar(1000)
BEGIN 
	DECLARE @OverPunchCodes varchar(20)
	DECLARE @OverPunchValues varchar(20)
	declare @OverPunch varchar(1)
	declare @overPunchValuePosition int
	Declare @overPunchColumnLength int
	declare @convertedField varchar(1000)

	set @OverPunchCodes  = '{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQR}'
	set @OverPunchValues = '01234567891234567890'
	set @overPunchField = ltrim(rtrim(@overPunchField))
	set @overPunchColumnLength =  len(@overPunchField)
	set @OverPunch = SUBSTRING(@overPunchField,@overPunchColumnLength,1 )
	select  @overPunchValuePosition = CHARINDEX(@OverPunch,@OverPunchCodes)
	
	if (@overPunchValuePosition <> 0) 
	begin
		set @convertedField = SUBSTRING(@overPunchField,1,@overPunchColumnLength-1 )+SUBSTRING( @OverPunchValues, @overPunchValuePosition,1 )
		if (@overPunchValuePosition > 10)
			set @overPunchField =  ( '-' + @convertedField)
		else
			set @overPunchField = @convertedField
	end

	return @overPunchField -- return @overPunchField
END

chatgpt_explanation.explanation:
#### 1. Overview
The `ConvertOverpunch` function is a scalar function in Microsoft SQL Server designed to convert overpunched numeric values into standard numeric values. Overpunching is a technique used in mainframe systems where the last digit of a number is replaced with a letter to indicate the sign of the number. This function interprets such characters and converts them into a numeric format that SQL Server can process.

#### 2. Complexity Level: Medium
The complexity level of this function is medium. While the logic of converting overpunched characters to numeric values is straightforward, it involves understanding the mapping between characters and numeric values, which requires some domain-specific knowledge.

#### 3. Input Parameters
- **@overpunchValue (VARCHAR or CHAR)**: This parameter represents the overpunched numeric value as a string. The function expects this input to be a character string where the last character be an overpunched character indicating the sign and the last digit of the number.

#### 4. Return Type
- **Return Type: DECIMAL or NUMERIC**: The function returns a numeric value, in a DECIMAL or NUMERIC format, which represents the converted value of the overpunched input. The exact precision and scale depend on the implementation details of the function.

#### 5. Business Logic and Workflow
1. **Character Mapping**: The function contains a mapping of overpunched characters to their corresponding numeric values and signs. For example, 'A' to 'I' represent 1 to 9 with a positive sign, while 'J' to 'R' represent 1 to 9 with a negative sign.
2. **String Manipulation**: The function extracts the last character of the input string to determine if it is an overpunched character.
3. **Conversion Logic**: Based on the extracted character, the function determines the numeric value and sign. It then constructs the complete numeric value by replacing the overpunched character with its corresponding digit and applying the sign.
4. **Return Value**: The function returns the computed numeric value.

#### 6. Performance Considerations
- **String Operations**: The function involves string manipulation, which can be computationally expensive if the function is called frequently or on large datasets.
- **Character Mapping**: The efficiency of the function depends on how the character mapping is implemented. A well-optimized mapping (e.g., using a CASE statement or a lookup table) can improve performance.
- **Scalar Nature**: As a scalar function, it is executed row-by-row, which can impact performance in set-based operations.

- **Character Set Limitations**: The function assumes a specific character set for overpunched values. If the input data uses a different character set or encoding, the function may not work correctly.

CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[ConvertOverpunch10] (@overPunchField varchar(10) )
RETURNS    varchar(11)
BEGIN 
-- Declare variables
   DECLARE @convertedField   varchar(10)
   DECLARE @overPunchColumnLength int
   DECLARE @overPunchValuePosition int
   DECLARE @OverPunchCodes varchar(20)
   DECLARE @OverPunchValues varchar(20)
   DECLARE @OverPunch varchar(1)
--
  set @OverPunchCodes  = '{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQR}'
  set @OverPunchValues = '01234567891234567890'
--
--   set @overPunchColumnLength = len(@overPunchField)
   set @overPunchColumnLength = 10
   set  @OverPunch =  SUBSTRING(@overPunchField,10,1 )
   select  @overPunchValuePosition = CHARINDEX(@OverPunch,@OverPunchCodes)
--
   if (@overPunchValuePosition = 0) return @overPunchField
--
  set @convertedField = SUBSTRING(@overPunchField,1,@overPunchColumnLength-1 )+SUBSTRING( @OverPunchValues, @overPunchValuePosition,1 )

  if (@overPunchValuePosition > 10) 
	   return ( '-' + @convertedField)

return @convertedField
END

function_info.name: ConvertOverpunch3
function_info.definition:
CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[ConvertOverpunch3] (@overPunchField varchar(3) )
RETURNS    varchar(3)
BEGIN 
-- Declare variables
   DECLARE @convertedField   varchar(3)
   DECLARE @overPunchColumnLength int
   DECLARE @overPunchValuePosition int
   DECLARE @OverPunchCodes varchar(20)
   DECLARE @OverPunchValues varchar(20)
   DECLARE @OverPunch varchar(1)
--
  set @OverPunchCodes  = '{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQR}'
  set @OverPunchValues = '01234567891234567890'
--
  set @overPunchColumnLength = 3

   set  @OverPunch =  SUBSTRING(@overPunchField,3,1 )
   select  @overPunchValuePosition = CHARINDEX(@OverPunch,@OverPunchCodes)

   if (@overPunchValuePosition = 0) return @overPunchField
--
  set @convertedField = SUBSTRING(@overPunchField,1,@overPunchColumnLength-1 )+SUBSTRING( @OverPunchValues, @overPunchValuePosition,1 )

  if (@overPunchValuePosition > 10) 
	   return ( '-' + @convertedField)

return @convertedField
END

function_info.name: ConvertOverpunch7
function_info.definition:
CREATE   FUNCTION [dbo].[ConvertOverpunch7] (@overPunchField varchar(7) )
RETURNS    varchar(8)
BEGIN 
-- Declare variables
   DECLARE @convertedField   varchar(7)
   DECLARE @overPunchColumnLength int
   DECLARE @overPunchValuePosition int
   DECLARE @OverPunchCodes varchar(20)
   DECLARE @OverPunchValues varchar(20)
   DECLARE @OverPunch varchar(1)
--
  set @OverPunchCodes  = '{ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQR}'
  set @OverPunchValues = '01234567891234567890'
--
  set @overPunchColumnLength = 7

   set  @OverPunch =  SUBSTRING(@overPunchField,7,1 )
   select  @overPunchValuePosition = CHARINDEX(@OverPunch,@OverPunchCodes)

   if (@overPunchValuePosition = 0) return @overPunchField
--
  set @convertedField = SUBSTRING(@overPunchField,1,@overPunchColumnLength-1 )+SUBSTRING( @OverPunchValues, @overPunchValuePosition,1 )

  if (@overPunchValuePosition > 10) 
	   return ( '-' + @convertedField)

return @convertedField
END

CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[ConvertStringDateToDate] ( @yyyymmdd varchar(8))
RETURNS smalldatetime AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @yyyy Varchar(4)
declare @mm  Varchar(2)
declare @dd   Varchar(2)

set @yyyy = substring(@yyyymmdd,1,4)
set @mm  = substring(@yyyymmdd,5,2)
set @dd = substring(@yyyymmdd,7,2)
--
return Cast((@yyyy+'-'+@mm+'-'+@dd) as smalldatetime)
END

function_info.name: CreateCoverSheetPdfFilename
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CreateCoverSheetPdfFilename] (@BillingPeriod varchar(6),@UtilityComapnySeqid integer)
RETURNS  ldesc AS  
BEGIN 
declare @CoverSheetPdfFilename ldesc
-- Build a Voucher Number from the input
if (@UtilityComapnySeqid = 7 ) -- NYPA Sequence id
	set @CoverSheetPdfFilename = 'Cust18_' + substring(@BillingPeriod,5,2)+substring(@BillingPeriod,3,2)+ '.pdf'
else if (@UtilityComapnySeqid = 9 ) -- Con Edison Sequence id
 	set @CoverSheetPdfFilename = 'Con Edsion Gas Total billed for_' + @BillingPeriod + '.pdf'
else if (@UtilityComapnySeqid = 2 ) -- Keyspan West  Sequence id
 	set @CoverSheetPdfFilename = 'Keyspan West  Gas Total billed for_' + @BillingPeriod + '.pdf'
else
 	set @CoverSheetPdfFilename = 'Total Amount billed for_' + @BillingPeriod + '.pdf'
return  @CoverSheetPdfFilename
END

function_info.name: CreateExchangedAccountNextPeriod
function_info.definition:
CREATE   FUNCTION [dbo].[CreateExchangedAccountNextPeriod] (@YYYYMM varchar(6),@BillingCycle varchar(1),@StatusCode varchar(2))  
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  
--
BEGIN 
	if (@StatusCode =  'AX')
		Begin
			return @YYYYMM
		End
	else
		Begin
			if @YYYYMM ='187601'  return '187601'
				declare @mm integer
				declare @yy integer
--				
				set @mm = cast(substring(@YYYYMM,5,2) as integer) +[dbo].[MonthsInBillingCycle]  (@BillingCycle)
				set @yy = cast(substring(@YYYYMM,1,4) as integer) 
--
				if @mm < 10  return substring( @YYYYMM,1,4)+'0'+  cast( (@mm) as varchar(1))
				else if 9 < @mm and @mm < 13 return substring( @YYYYMM,1,4) +  cast( (@mm) as varchar(2))
				else if @mm > 12 and @BillingCycle = 'M' return cast( (@yy+1) as varchar(4))+'01'
				else if @mm > 12 and @BillingCycle = 'B' return cast( (@yy+1) as varchar(4))+'02'
				else if @mm > 12 and @BillingCycle = 'Q' return cast( (@yy+1) as varchar(4))+'03'
				else if @mm > 12 and @BillingCycle = 'Y' return cast( (@yy+1) as varchar(4))+substring(@YYYYMM,5,2)
		End
	return '187601'
END

function_info.name: CreateFiscalYear
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CreateFiscalYear] (@YYYYMM varchar(6),@Current varchar(1))  
RETURNS varchar(4) AS  
BEGIN 
declare @FiscalYearAdjustment integer
-- "C"urrent Fiscal Year or "P"revious Fiscal Year
if @Current ='C' set @FiscalYearAdjustment = 0 else set @FiscalYearAdjustment = -1
declare @mm integer
declare @yy integer
set @mm = cast(substring(@YYYYMM,5,2) as integer)
set @yy = cast(substring(@YYYYMM,1,4) as integer)  + @FiscalYearAdjustment
if 6 < @mm and @mm <= 12 return cast( (@yy+1) as varchar(4))
else   return cast( (@yy) as varchar(4))
return '1876'
END

function_info.name: CreateFiscalYearPeriod
function_info.definition:
CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[CreateFiscalYearPeriod] (@YYYYMM varchar(6),@StartEnd varchar(1))  
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  
BEGIN 
declare @FiscalYearMonth varchar(2)
declare @FiscalYearAdj integer
declare @yy integer
--
-- "S"tart of the Fiscal Year or "E"nd of the Fiscal Year 
--
if @StartEnd ='S' 
   begin
      set @FiscalYearMonth = '07' 
      set @FiscalYearAdj = -1
   end
else
   begin
      set @FiscalYearMonth = '06' 
      set @FiscalYearAdj = 0
   end
--
set @yy = cast([dbo].[CreateFiscalYear] (@YYYYMM,'C') as integer)
--
return cast( (@yy+@FiscalYearAdj) as varchar(4)) + cast( (@FiscalYearMonth) as varchar(2))
END

		Begin
			if @YYYYMM ='187601'  return '187601'

function_info.name: CreateNextPeriod
function_info.definition:
CREATE   FUNCTION [dbo].[CreateNextPeriod] (@YYYYMMDD varchar(6),@BillingCycle varchar(1))  
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  
BEGIN 
if @YYYYMMDD ='18760101'  return '187601'
declare @mm integer
declare @yy integer
set @mm = cast(substring(@YYYYMMDD,5,2) as integer) +[dbo].[MonthsInBillingCycle]  (@BillingCycle)
set @yy = cast(substring(@YYYYMMDD,1,4) as integer) 
if @mm < 10  return substring( @YYYYMMDD,1,4)+'0'+  cast( (@mm) as varchar(1))
else if 9 < @mm and @mm < 13 return substring( @YYYYMMDD,1,4) +  cast( (@mm) as varchar(2))
else if @mm > 12 and @BillingCycle = 'M' return cast( (@yy+1) as varchar(4))+'01'
else if @mm > 12 and @BillingCycle = 'B' return cast( (@yy+1) as varchar(4))+'0'+ cast((@mm-12) as varchar(1))
else if @mm > 12 and @BillingCycle = 'Q' return cast( (@yy+1) as varchar(4))+'0'+ cast((@mm-12) as varchar(1))
else if @mm > 12 and @BillingCycle = 'Y' return cast( (@yy+1) as varchar(4))+substring(@YYYYMMDD,5,2)
--return '187601'
return null
END

BEGIN 
--

END

function_info.name: CreateVoucherNumber
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[CreateVoucherNumber] (@BillingPeriod varchar(6),@UtilityComapnySeqid integer, @VoucherSequenceNumber integer)  
RETURNS varchar(11) AS  
BEGIN 
-- Build a Voucher Number from the input
declare @VoucherNumber varchar(11)
declare @YYMM varchar(4)
declare @UtilityCompany varchar(2)
declare @SequenceNumber varchar(3)
declare @OriginalBilling char(1) ="^"
--
set @YYMM = substring(@BillingPeriod,3,4)
--
if (@UtilityComapnySeqid < 10)
    set @UtilityCompany = '0'+ cast(@UtilityComapnySeqid as varchar(1))
else
   set @UtilityCompany = cast(@UtilityComapnySeqid as varchar(2))
--
if (@OriginalBilling ='P')  
   Begin
      if (@VoucherSequenceNumber < 10)
          set @SequenceNumber = '00'+ cast(@VoucherSequenceNumber as varchar(1))
      else
          set @SequenceNumber = '0'+ cast(@VoucherSequenceNumber as varchar(2))
   End
else
   Begin
      if (@VoucherSequenceNumber < 10)
          set @SequenceNumber = '00'+ cast(@VoucherSequenceNumber as varchar(1))
      else if (9 < @VoucherSequenceNumber  and @VoucherSequenceNumber < 100)
          set @SequenceNumber = '0'+ cast(@VoucherSequenceNumber as varchar(2))
      else
          set @SequenceNumber =  cast(@VoucherSequenceNumber as varchar(3))
   End
--
set @VoucherNumber ='DEM' + @UtilityCompany + @YYMM + @SequenceNumber
--
return  @VoucherNumber
END

declare @WinterYearStart Varchar(4)
declare @WinterYearEnd  Varchar(4)
declare @mm integer
declare @yyyy integer
--
set @mm = cast(substring(@CurrentBillingPeriod,5,2) as integer)
set @yyyy = cast(substring(@CurrentBillingPeriod,1,4) as integer) 
--
if (11 <= @mm and @mm <= 12) 
 Begin
  set @WinterYearStart = cast((@yyyy) as varchar(4)) 
  set @WinterYearEnd = cast((@yyyy+1) as varchar(4)) 
end 
 else 
 Begin
  set @WinterYearStart = cast((@yyyy-1) as varchar(4)) 
  set @WinterYearEnd = cast((@yyyy) as varchar(4)) 
end 
--
if @StartEnd ='S' return @WinterYearStart + '11' else return @WinterYearEnd + '04'
return '1876'
END

function_info.name: DateFormat
function_info.definition:
create FUNCTION [dbo].[DateFormat]  (@date varchar(6),@type varchar(1))
--
RETURNS varchar(20) AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @year varchar(4)
declare @month int
--
if (@type=1)
begin
set @year = substring(@date,1,4)
set @month = cast(substring(@date,4,2) as integer)
return DATENAME(month, @date+'01') + ' ' + @year
end

return 0
--
END

function_info.name: DefineEnergySource
function_info.definition:
CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[DefineEnergySource]  (@EnergyDescription varchar(3))
--
RETURNS int AS  
BEGIN 
--
if (@EnergyDescription = 'ELE') return 1		-- Electric
   else if (@EnergyDescription = 'GAS') return 2	-- Gas
   else if (@EnergyDescription = 'STM') return 3	-- Steam
   else if (@EnergyDescription = 'CHW') return 4	-- Chilled Water
   else if (@EnergyDescription = 'OIL') return 5	-- Oil
   else return 0					-- Unknown (Default)
  
--
RETURN 0
END

function_info.name: DefineNextPeriod
function_info.definition:
CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[DefineNextPeriod]  (@seqid integer,  @BillingPeriod integer)  
--
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  
BEGIN 
declare @NextBillingPeriodOffset  integer
declare @GreaterThan36 integer
declare @GreaterThan36BillingPeriod integer
--
set @NextBillingPeriodOffset = [dbo].[MOD] (@seqid,36 )
set @GreaterThan36  = @NextBillingPeriodOffset  + @BillingPeriod
set @GreaterThan36BillingPeriod = @GreaterThan36 - 36
--
if (@NextBillingPeriodOffset = 0 and @BillingPeriod =  1) return '200407'
   else if @NextBillingPeriodOffset = 0 and @BillingPeriod =  2  return '200408'
   else if @NextBillingPeriodOffset = 0 and @BillingPeriod =  3 return '200409'
   else if @NextBillingPeriodOffset = 0 and @BillingPeriod =  12 return '200506'
   else if @GreaterThan36 > 36  and @GreaterThan36BillingPeriod = 1 return '200407'
   else if @GreaterThan36 > 36  and @GreaterThan36BillingPeriod = 2 return '200408'
   else if @GreaterThan36 > 36  and @GreaterThan36BillingPeriod = 3 return '200409'
   else if @GreaterThan36 > 36  and @GreaterThan36BillingPeriod = 12 return '200506'
   else return 'XXXXXX'
  
--
RETURN 'AAAAAA'
END

END

CREATE   FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineBillingPeriodProjected] (@ToDate varchar(8),@Utility int)

BEGIN 

declare @BillingPeriod varchar(6)

SELECT @BillingPeriod=BillingPeriod FROM Billing.BillingPeriodProjected WHERE UtilityCompanySeqid=@Utility AND StartofPeriodTodate<=@ToDate AND EndofPeriodTodate >= @ToDate

return @BillingPeriod

END

function_info.name: DetermineConEdisonActualOrEstimatedBilling
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineConEdisonActualOrEstimatedBilling] (
	@AccountNumber varchar(15) , 
	@BillingPeriodRevision varchar(6) )  
  RETURNS varchar(3) 
  
AS BEGIN 


declare @ReadingCode varchar(2)
declare @ReadingCodeCount int
declare @MissingReadingCodeCount int
--
SELECT	@ReadingCode = MIN(ReadingCode), @ReadingCodeCount = COUNT(*)
FROM	ConEd.UploadConEdisonMeter
GROUP BY
		AccountNumber, BillingPeriodRevision
HAVING
		(AccountNumber = @AccountNumber) AND (BillingPeriodRevision = @BillingPeriodRevision)
--
set @MissingReadingCodeCount = @@rowcount
--
return CASE
		WHEN @MissingReadingCodeCount = 0 then 'EST' 
		ELSE 
			--CASE when @ReadingCode > '15' then 'ACT' else 'EST' END 
			dbo.CalculateEstimatedOrActual(@ReadingCode,9) 
	   END
END

CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineConEdisonBillingPeriodProjected] (@ToDate varchar(8),@Tariff varchar(3),@Utility int)

BEGIN

--

	Begin
		SELECT @BillingPeriod=MIN(BillingPeriod) FROM Billing.BillingPeriodProjected WHERE UtilityCompanySeqid=@Utility AND EndofPeriodTodate >= @ToDate
	End
else
	Begin
		set @BillingPeriod=substring(@ToDate,1,6)
	End

--
return @BillingPeriod

END

function_info.name: DetermineConEdisonBillingPeriodProjectedFromDate
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineConEdisonBillingPeriodProjectedFromDate] (@BillingPeriod varchar(6),@Tariff varchar(3),@Utility int)
RETURNS varchar(8) AS  

BEGIN 

declare @EndofPeriodTodate varchar(8)
declare @Year int
declare @Month varchar(2)
--
if (@Tariff < '100')
	Begin
		SELECT @EndofPeriodTodate = EndofPeriodTodate FROM Billing.BillingPeriodProjected 
		   where (BillingPeriod = [dbo].[CreatePreviousPeriod] (@BillingPeriod,'M')) and UtilityCompanySeqid=@Utility
	End
else
	Begin
		set @BillingPeriod = [dbo].[CreatePreviousPeriod] (@BillingPeriod,'M')
		set @Year = Cast(substring(@BillingPeriod,1,4) as int)
		set @month = substring(@BillingPeriod,5,2)
		set @EndofPeriodTodate=@BillingPeriod + CASE  
											WHEN @month in ('01','03','05','07','08','10','12') THEN '31'
											WHEN @month in ('04','06','09','11') THEN '30'
											WHEN @month = '02' then Case when @Year % 4 =0 then '29' else '28' end
										  END
	End
--
return @EndofPeriodTodate

END

CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineConEdisonGetGasTariffRateFromAccountTable] (@AccountNumber varchar(15),@BillingPeriodRevision varchar(6))
RETURNS varchar(3) AS  

BEGIN 

declare @TariffCode varchar(3)
declare @MissingTariffCode int
--
-- Assume that the account will have the same Gas Rate code for all of the trasnactions for the 
-- billing period.
--
SELECT  top 1 @TariffCode = TariffCode
FROM ConEd.UploadConEdisonAccount
WHERE  (AccountNumber = @AccountNumber) -- and (BillingPeriodRevision =@BillingPeriodRevision )
order by TariffCode desc
--
set @MissingTariffCode = @@rowcount
--
--	Use the fudged Therm factor of 1.03 as per Stuart Barth 6/27/2008
return Case when @MissingTariffCode = 0 then 'XXX' else @TariffCode end

END

CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineConEdisonGetPostingDateFromAccountTable] (@AccountNumber varchar(15),@BillingPeriodRevision varchar(6))
RETURNS DateTime AS  

BEGIN 

declare @PostingDate DateTime
declare @MissingPostingDate int
--
SELECT @PostingDate = PostingDate
FROM ConEd.UploadConEdisonAccount
WHERE (BillingPeriodRevision =@BillingPeriodRevision ) AND (AccountNumber = @AccountNumber)

function_info.name: DetermineConEdisonGetThermFactorFromAccountTable
function_info.definition:
CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineConEdisonGetThermFactorFromAccountTable] (@AccountNumber varchar(15),@BillingPeriodRevision varchar(6))
RETURNS numeric(6,4) AS  

BEGIN 

declare @ThermFactor numeric(6,4)
declare @ThermFactorCount int
declare @MissingThermFactor int
--
SELECT	@ThermFactor = ThermFactor, @ThermFactorCount = COUNT(*)
FROM	ConEd.UploadConEdisonAccount
GROUP BY
		AccountNumber, BillingPeriodRevision, ThermFactor
HAVING
		(AccountNumber = @AccountNumber) AND (BillingPeriodRevision = @BillingPeriodRevision)

set @MissingThermFactor = @@rowcount
--
--	Use the fudged Therm factor of 1.03 as per Stuart Barth 6/27/2008
return Case when @MissingThermFactor = 0 then 1.03 else @ThermFactor end

END

Create FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineDateRelativeToBillingPeriod](@BillingPeriod varchar(6),@BillingCycle varchar(1),@NumberOfDays int)
--
RETURNS DateTime AS  
BEGIN 
declare @DeltaDays int 
set @DeltaDays = @NumberOfDays*[dbo].[MonthsInBillingCycle]  (@BillingCycle)
--
--select CONVERT(DATETIME, '20061019 00:00:00', 102)

return DATEADD(day, @DeltaDays, CONVERT(DATETIME,@BillingPeriod+ '01 00:00:00', 102))
END

function_info.name: DetermineFiscalYear
function_info.definition:
Create FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineFiscalYear]
--ALTER FUNCTION dbo.DetermineFiscalYear
    (
     @BillingPeriod VARCHAR(40)
    )
RETURNS VARCHAR(4)
AS
    BEGIN
        DECLARE @YR1 VARCHAR(4) = '1900'
        DECLARE @YR2 VARCHAR(4) = '1900'
        DECLARE @FiscalYear VARCHAR(4)

        SET @YR1 = CONCAT(LEFT(@BillingPeriod, 4), '07')

        SET @YR2 = CONCAT(LEFT(@BillingPeriod, 4), '12')

        SET @FiscalYear = CASE WHEN @BillingPeriod >= @YR1
                                    AND @BillingPeriod <= @YR2
                               THEN CAST(CAST(LEFT(@BillingPeriod, 4) AS INT) + 1 AS VARCHAR(4))
                               ELSE CAST(LEFT(@BillingPeriod, 4) AS VARCHAR(4))
                          END

        RETURN @FiscalYear
    END

function_info.name: DetermineKeyspanWestBillingPeriodHold
function_info.definition:
CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineKeyspanWestBillingPeriodHold] (@CurrentBillingPeriod varchar(6),@EvenBillingPeriod varchar(6),@OddBillingPeriod varchar(6),
                                                           @IsFudgedRevisedBilling varchar(1),@CrisOrSpecialLedger integer,@BillingDays int)
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  

BEGIN 
--
declare @WdNumber integer
declare @BillingCycle varchar(1)
--
declare @RawPeriod varchar(6)
--
if (@EvenBillingPeriod > @OddBillingPeriod) 
    Begin
       if (@OddBillingPeriod > @CurrentBillingPeriod) set @RawPeriod = @CurrentBillingPeriod else set @RawPeriod = @OddBillingPeriod
    end
else
    Begin
       if (@EvenBillingPeriod > @CurrentBillingPeriod) set @RawPeriod = @CurrentBillingPeriod else set @RawPeriod = @EvenBillingPeriod
    end

if (@IsFudgedRevisedBilling = 'Y')
   Begin
      return @RawPeriod
   End
else
   Begin
	if (@CrisOrSpecialLedger = 3) set @BillingCycle = 'M' else set @BillingCycle = 'B'

        return [dbo].MinValue([dbo].[CreateNextPeriod] (@RawPeriod,@BillingCycle),@CurrentBillingPeriod)
   End
--
return 'XXXXXX'
END

CREATE  FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineKeyspanWestBorough] (@AccountNumber varchar(15))  
RETURNS varchar(1) AS  
BEGIN 
--
declare @b varchar(3)
declare @boroughCode varchar(1)
--
set @b = substring( @AccountNumber,2,3)
set  @boroughCode = '0
--'
if ('000'<= @b and @b <= '065') set @boroughCode = '3'
else if ('066'<= @b and @b <= '169') set @boroughCode = '4'
else if ('200'<= @b and @b <= '209') set @boroughCode = '3'
else if ('220'<= @b and @b <= '239') set @boroughCode = '3'
else if ( @b = '915') set @boroughCode = '5'
 
return @boroughCode

END

function_info.name: DetermineKeyspanWestCrisBillingPeriod
function_info.definition:
CREATE      FUNCTION [dbo].[DetermineKeyspanWestCrisBillingPeriod] (@EvenBillingPeriod varchar(6),@OddBillingPeriod varchar(6),@IsFudgedRevisedBilling varchar(1),@CrisOrSpecialLedger integer,@BillingDays int)
RETURNS varchar(6) AS  

BEGIN 
--
declare @WdNumber integer
declare @BillingCycle varchar(1)
--
if (@IsFudgedRevisedBilling = 'Y')
   Begin
	if (@EvenBillingPeriod > @OddBillingPeriod) 
	    return @OddBillingPeriod
	else
	    return @EvenBillingPeriod
   End
else
   Begin
	if (@CrisOrSpecialLedger = 3) set @BillingCycle = 'M' else set @BillingCycle = 'B'

	if (@CrisOrSpecialLedger = 3 and @BillingDays < 28 and @EvenBillingPeriod > @OddBillingPeriod)
	    --return @OddBillingPeriod
	    return [dbo].[CreateNextPeriod] (@OddBillingPeriod,@BillingCycle)
	if (@EvenBillingPeriod > @OddBillingPeriod) 
	    --return @EvenBillingPeriod
	    return [dbo].[CreateNextPeriod] (@EvenBillingPeriod,@BillingCycle)
          else 
 	    --return @OddBillingPeriod
	    return [dbo].[CreateNextPeriod] (@OddBillingPeriod,@BillingCycle)
   End

   return @OddBillingPeriod


--
return '20'
END
